close_symbols: struct linux_driver (definition, including dev_open/dev_close and sdrv members)
struct list_head (definition) and related list macros
Any macro definitions used by the above (e.g. typeof, __attribute__, statement-expression usage, __extension__)
explanation: To determine whether the target function uses language/compiler extensions you must inspect any macros, inline helpers and type/container macros it relies on. The for_each_linux_driver macro and the kernel-style list iteration macros often expand via container_of/list macros that in Linux code commonly use GCC extensions (e.g. typeof, statement-expressions, or __attribute__). to_linux_bus may itself be a macro using container_of/typeof. Inspecting the struct definitions (linux_driver, linux_device, linux_bus, metal_device) is needed to see whether any fields are defined with compiler-specific attributes or whether function-pointer members use nonstandard prototypes. The list_head and list-related macros and the implementation of metal_list_add_tail must be checked to ensure they do not use compiler extensions. Finally, any underlying macro primitives (typeof, __attribute__, ({ ... }) statement-expressions, __extension__, inline asm, etc.) must be known because those are the explicit language extensions MISRA requires reporting.
